author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Staff)
title: Evolution of the Labyrinth
text:
Evolution of the Labyrinth Oct 16, 2015 Dee Clark painted this labyrinth on the parking lot of the University of Maine’s Hutchinson Center in Belfast. 
Camden — As part of its evening program series, the Camden Philosophical Society will host a talk by Chris Glass titled The Evolution of the Labyrinth Tuesday, Oct. 27, at 7 p.m. at Camden Public Library. All are welcome. 
Camden architect Glass will explore the history of the labyrinth, from its occurrences in prehistory to its resurgence in recent years as a place for spiritual practices. This lecture is based on a course given last spring at the Senior College in Belfast. 
Attendees will learn the historical distinctions between labyrinths and mazes; learn how to draw the classical labyrinth and its variants — Greek and Roman labyrinths, the legend of Theseus and Ariadne, Daedalus and Icarus, and the Roman labyrinths based on the legend; medieval church labyrinths showing how Theseus became the Armed Man and the Minotaur became Satan; musical labyrinths and the circle of fifths. 
Also considered will be puzzle mazes from their origins to contemporary examples, including mazes in films; and contemplative labyrinths, hearing what their makers and users have to say about them. The free talk is part of the library’s Discover History month. 
Courier Publications’ A&E Editor Dagney C. Ernest can be reached at (207) 594-4401, ext. 115; or dernest@courierpublicationsllc.com.
